metadata.title: Convert Horsepower to Kilowatts – Power Converter
metadata.description: Convert power from horsepower (hp) to kilowatts (kW) using the exact conversion factor, suitable for motor specifications, automotive applications, and equipment performance comparisons.

introduction: This converter transforms power measurements from horsepower (hp) to kilowatts (kW), bridging imperial and metric power standards. It is designed for engineers, automotive professionals, and technicians who need to convert North American equipment power ratings to international metric specifications.

Horsepower is traditional in North American automotive, industrial, and legacy equipment, while the kilowatt is the SI metric standard used in modern technical codes, international specifications, and scientific work. Understanding this conversion is essential for equipment selection, performance comparison, and international technical documentation.

The converter applies the exact, mathematically derived relationship between the mechanical horsepower (defined as 745.7 watts) and the kilowatt, ensuring reliable results for motor nameplates, equipment specifications, and performance ratings.
methodology: Horsepower (hp) is defined as 745.7 watts, derived from the historical definition of work rate. The kilowatt (kW) is a unit of power equal to 1,000 watts in the SI system. The exact relationship is: 1 hp = 0.745700 kW (or equivalently, 1 kW = 1.34102 hp). This factor is standardized globally in electrical machinery standards and equipment specifications.

To convert a power value from horsepower to kilowatts, you multiply the hp value by 0.745700. For example, 100 hp = 74.57 kW, 50 hp = 37.285 kW, and 150 hp = 111.855 kW. This conversion is used consistently in automotive performance data, motor specifications, and international equipment comparisons.

The converter applies full-precision floating-point multiplication internally to maintain maximum numerical accuracy. Results are displayed rounded to practical precision (typically two to three decimal places), suitable for equipment documentation, performance specifications, and technical work.

Because the conversion factor is exact and standardized, this converter produces results consistent with IEEE electrical machinery standards, SAE automotive specifications, and international equipment labeling requirements used by manufacturers worldwide.
examples: Example 1 – Automotive engine: A typical North American car engine rated at 100 hp converts to approximately 74.57 kW, the metric equivalent commonly listed on international vehicle documentation.
Example 2 – Industrial motor: A common industrial motor rated at 50 hp converts to approximately 37.29 kW, a standard specification for machinery and compressor equipment.
Example 3 – Marine propulsion: A boat engine rated at 300 hp converts to approximately 223.71 kW, typical for commercial marine applications and yacht power ratings.
Example 4 – Agricultural equipment: A large tractor engine rated at 200 hp converts to approximately 149.14 kW, a typical specification for heavy agricultural machinery.

faqs.question: What is the exact conversion from horsepower to kilowatts?
faqs.answer: The exact factor is 1 hp = 0.745700 kW. To convert any power in hp to kW, multiply by 0.745700. This factor is derived from the standardized definition of mechanical horsepower (745.7 watts) and is used globally by equipment manufacturers and standards bodies.

faqs.question: Why do vehicles sold in different regions have different power ratings?
faqs.answer: North American vehicles are traditionally rated in horsepower, while European and Asian vehicles are rated in kilowatts. The actual engine power is identical—only the units differ. This converter allows you to compare vehicle performance across different regional specifications.

faqs.question: How do I quickly estimate hp to kilowatts?
faqs.answer: A useful approximation is to multiply hp by 0.75 to get a rough kW value. For example, 100 hp × 0.75 = 75 kW (actual: 74.57 kW), accurate to within about 0.6%. This mental math works well for quick performance comparisons.

faqs.question: Is this conversion accurate enough for equipment selection?
faqs.answer: Yes. The conversion factor 0.745700 is the standard used by motor manufacturers, IEEE electrical standards, and automotive industry specifications worldwide. When comparing or selecting equipment across regions, this exact factor ensures accuracy and consistency.

faqs.question: What precision should I use for equipment ratings?
faqs.answer: For most equipment documentation and technical work, two decimal places are sufficient. For detailed engineering calculations or formal specifications, maintain three significant figures (e.g., 100 hp = 74.6 kW). Always follow your equipment manufacturer's documentation for required precision.

faqs.question: Can I use this converter for all types of power?
faqs.answer: Yes. The conversion factor applies equally to mechanical power (motor output, engine performance), electrical power (generator output, motor input), and any other form of power measured in horsepower or kilowatts.

faqs.question: How do motor nameplates typically use both horsepower and kilowatts?
faqs.answer: Many modern equipment nameplates display both units for international compatibility. The hp rating is typically the primary specification in North America, while kW is listed as equivalent for users in metric countries. Both values are mathematically related by the exact conversion factor.

faqs.question: Why is horsepower still used if kilowatts are metric standard?
faqs.answer: Horsepower remains in use because of historical standardization in North American industries, regulatory requirements, and consumer familiarity. Many equipment manufacturers, automotive companies, and industrial suppliers continue using hp for compatibility with existing standards and market expectations.

glossary.definition: An imperial unit of power equal to 745.7 watts. Historically defined as the work rate of a horse and remains standard in North American automotive, industrial, and equipment specifications.
A metric unit of power equal to 1,000 watts. The standard power unit in SI and used in international equipment specifications, electrical systems, and renewable energy applications.
The SI base unit of power, equal to one joule per second (J/s). One kilowatt equals 1,000 watts. The watt is the foundation of all SI power measurements.
Power associated with physical motion, work, or machinery. Measured in horsepower (imperial) or kilowatts (metric). Used in motor ratings, automotive performance, and equipment specifications.

Power associated with electrical current and voltage. Measured in kilowatts (metric) or horsepower-equivalents (imperial). Used in electrical system ratings, motor specifications, and utility measurements.
